speaker: Teacher
text: The party, "the party" in French is "la fête."

speaker: Teacher
text: Like we have in English school fête, no? A school party in English is a school fête. So that's interesting, we took the, the French word for party, "fête," and we, we used it in English just to describe one particular type of party. And it's not spelled like English. The French, the French is spelled "F-E-T-E." And the first E has a little hat on it. It has an accent mark over it. It looks like a, like a triangle without the bottom, like a little hat. And that gives us "fête." [French 'eh' sound] "La fête." [French 'eh' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: How would you say, "You must organize the party"? "You must organize the party."

speaker: Teacher
text: Think about one bit at a time.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois organiser la fête." [French 'eh' sound] Good. "I have to organize it." "I must organize it."

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. And what happens to "la"? You use "la," no? 'Cause you were thinking about the party, organizing the party, which is great. But what happens to "la" and "organiser" when they come together?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je dois l'organiser." So we get "l'organiser." We lose the A of "la." "Je dois l'organiser." So talking about the party, "la fête," [French 'eh' sound] we, we use "la" for it. But what if you were talking about something more general, like getting it done, "I have to organize it," like getting it done. What do you use for this general it?

speaker: Teacher
text: So yes, we would use "le," the masculine. So how would you say that? "I have to organize it," like getting it done or something general?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. Sounds the same, no? 'Cause of course the "le" and "organiser" blend together. "Je dois l'organiser." Very good. So "le" and "la," they both mean it. And apart from this, "le" and "la" also mean him and her. So now we can communicate many more ideas in French. How would you say "provocation"? "Provocation." Take it syllable by syllable.

speaker: Teacher
text: Provocation." [nasal 'a' sound] Good. And how would we get to "provoke"? We start with "provocation." [nasal 'a' sound] What do we do next?

speaker: Student
text: I finish the, the word in "E-R."

speaker: Teacher
text: Yes, but before you do that, what do you do?

speaker: Teacher
text: No? We have to get rid of that. So do that and slowly.

speaker: Teacher
text: Provoquer." To provoke. So how might you say "you want to provoke him"? We said that the word for it is the same as the word for him. "You want to provoke him."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux le provoquer." The word for "just," if you want to say something like, "You, you just want to provoke him," no? Is "juste," spelled "J-U-S-T-E." So spelled just like the English, but with an E on the end to let us know to pronounce that final consonant. "Juste."

speaker: Teacher
text: So "you just want to provoke him." In French we will say, "You want just..." The "just" will come there. "You want just." So how would that be? "You just want to provoke him."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux juste le provoquer." Very good. "You just want to provoke him." So again, we can look at the verb, like "provoquer," and we can identify two parts. We can identify "voquer," which is like related to "vocal." And then we have "pro," the little bit that we're adding onto the beginning. "To pro vocal." "To provoke." And this "pro" we can find around now, like in "provide," "profess," "promote." So we can identify now how "provoquer" is built of two parts, of that "pro" beginning and then that "voquer" base. And if we feel like it, when we notice that, we can experiment with it and play around and see what other words we might find in French from this "voquer." So for example, "to invoke." How might that be, "to invoke"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. But here the "I-N" gives us [nasal 'a' sound], "invoquer." [nasal 'a' sound] We could have revoke. "To revoke," like "to take away," "to take something away from somebody." How might that be in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. Révoquer." Good. So we didn't even need to go back to "ation" words, no, to find "révoquer." No, we could just do that switching between "provoquer," "provoke" and "invoke," "revoke," just by noticing how "provoke" was built. So it's just about getting in the habit of thinking curiously and bringing all this French we already have in our English closer to the surface through this habit of curiosity. "To see" in French is "voir." "Voir."

speaker: Teacher
text: Connected to view in English, "voir," "to see." So how might you say, "I want to see her"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux la voir." How might you say, "I just want to see her. I want just to see her"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux juste la voir." "I want to see him later." "I want to see him later."

speaker: Student
text: Je veux le voir plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux le voir plus tard." Very good. "Do you have to see him"? "Must you see him"? "Do you owe to see him"?

speaker: Teacher
text: What's the first bit? "You must," "must you."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Dois-tu" or "tu dois le voir." So, "voir" ends differently to the verbs we've seen so far, which end "E-R." "Voir" ends "I-R." So, "voir" ends "I-R" and we hear the R here in "voir." And "voir," "to see," like "dois," "must," like "voiture," "car," has this "O-I" combination giving us a "wa" sound. The word for "me" is the same in French, me. It's written the same but pronounced differently. It's written "M-E" just like in English so, how should that sound in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good, with a weak 'uh' sound [schwa sound] like in "je," [schwa sound] like in "le," [schwa sound] "me." [schwa sound] Very good. And "me" goes in the same position as "le" as "la." It's the same type of word so it follows the same rules about where it should go. So how would you say, "Do you want to see me"? "Do you want to see me"? So, the first bit is "do you want." That's the only bit you should think about for now.

speaker: Teacher
text: Good but not so much "me" but?

speaker: Teacher
text: Me. [schwa sound] Good. "Veux-tu me voir"? [schwa sound] "Do you want to see me"? Or just with the intonation only. "Tu veux me voir"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Can you see me"? [schwa sound] "Are you able to see me"? [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu peux" or "peux-tu me voir"? [schwa sound] "You must see me." [schwa sound] "You have to see me." [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Must you provoke" [laughs] "me." [schwa sound] "Must you provoke me"? [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu dois," "dois-tu me [schwa sound] provoquer"? Very good. So I used "provoquer" as another example of, you know, how we want to get in this habit always of analyzing vocabulary, and we found that we could have, for example, "revoquer" from the same "voquer" root. We could have "invoquer" which is "invoke" in English. So we noticed there how the "I-N" gave us the nasal 'in' sound, "invoquer," [nasal 'in' sound] and this is because again the N on the end of the syllable is getting swallowed into the vowel just like what we saw with "confirmer," [nasal 'a' sound] for example, "comparer." [nasal 'o' sound] The same thing is happening here, so we get the nasal 'in' for our nasal I. "Invoquer." [nasal 'in' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: So this will count for other "IN"s, no, that we find. So like, for example, if we want to say "invitation," how would that sound?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. We take away the "ation" and then we add our E, our "E-R" ending.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "To invite." [nasal 'in' sound] "Can you invite him"?

speaker: Student
text: Peux-tu, uh, peux-tu le... Peux-tu l'inviter?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very [laughs] good. So this was very good. You know, you thought there just that one bit at a time. Even though that forced you to rethink it a couple of times, look how quickly you could do that, thinking about just one thing at a time. Very good.

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. The same with the "me" here. We will blend "me" so we get "M apostrophe Inviter." [nasal 'in' sound]
